title: AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c have overlapping functions in pollen development and pollen tube growth
background: Rab GTPases regulate endomembrane trafficking, including exocytosis, endocytosis and membrane recycling. In plants, these proteins are crucial for intracellular transport processes, but only a subset have been functionally characterized.
objective: To determine the functional roles of AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c in plant development, particularly in pollen development and pollen tube growth
methods: T-DNA insertion mutants, genetic crosses, RT-PCR, SEM imaging, confocal microscopy, in vitro pollen germination assays, GUS staining, and bioinformatics analysis of expression patterns
results: AtrabD2b/2c double mutants showed shorter siliques, deformed pollen with swollen/branched tube tips, reduced pollen germination, and decreased pollen tube length. Single mutants had subtle defects while double mutants showed severe reproductive phenotypes.
conclusion: AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c are partially redundant Golgi-localized proteins essential for normal pollen development and pollen tube tip growth, with functions that cannot be fully compensated by other RabD family members.

learning_notes.note: AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c showed 77.81% correlation in expression patterns and 99% amino acid identity, indicating high functional redundancy. The double mutant exhibited severe reproductive defects while single mutants appeared normal, demonstrating that these genes can compensate for each other's functions in most tissues.

The AtrabD2b/2c double mutant produced siliques that were 70% the length of wild-type, with approximately 50% unfertilized ovules due to pollen defects. This demonstrates the critical role of these Rab GTPases in supporting the high secretory demands of rapidly growing pollen tubes.

Pollen from double mutants showed multiple abnormalities: 20% had collapsed morphology, some lacked nuclei by DAPI staining, 10% failed to germinate, and 50% of germinated pollen had swollen tips with some branching (2%) or bursting (5%). These defects highlight the importance of vesicle trafficking in tip growth.

Both AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c localized to Golgi bodies, colocalizing with the trans-Golgi marker ST-YFP in protoplast transient expression assays. This localization is consistent with their proposed role in ER-to-Golgi trafficking, essential for delivering membrane and cell wall components to growing pollen tube tips.

Cross-pollination experiments demonstrated that the fertility defect was pollen-specific: wild-type pollen completely rescued the double mutant silique phenotype, while double mutant pollen conferred the short-silique phenotype to wild-type plants, confirming the defect originates in the male gametophyte.

Expression analysis revealed both genes are highly expressed in pollen, with AtRabD2b showing vascular-specific expression in leaves and ubiquitous root expression, while AtRabD2c was expressed throughout leaves but excluded from root hairs and tips, indicating tissue-specific functional specialization.

The research was partially supported by NASA grant no. NNX09AK78G, indicating direct relevance to space biology applications, particularly for understanding plant reproduction mechanisms that could support food production in controlled environments during long-duration missions.
